Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: WIldlife Deterrence from Hazards Using High Brightness Ultraviolet Light
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project represents a new development in man?s ability to keep birds away from the airspace surrounding an airplane or out of the way of the massive rotors of wind turbines. Animals respond to a bright ultraviolet light in the same way as humans respond to a bright flashlight in their eyes. If the light is strong enough, it causes an involuntary behavioral response resulting in the animal being deterred from the area of the light source. Ultraviolet light has the advantage of being visible to most species of animals while being invisible to humans. This Phase II project builds on the Phase I project that demonstrated with 98% confidence that bird behavior is influenced by the presence of the wildlife deterrence system?s bright ultraviolet light in a completely natural environment with no human presence.


The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is focused on three high value applications of the wildlife deterrence system. They are renewable alternative energy (wind farms), air transportation (planes and airports), and agriculture (aquaculture and agriculture). Renewable energy is at the top of the U.S. priority list. Wind energy is one of the most promising forms of alternative energy. At the same time, there is an immediate and pressing need to reduce the mortality rate of endangered and protected species at wind farms. A compelling global need for the wildlife deterrence system is exemplified by the aviation industry and the incidence of bird strikes. The U.S. Department of Transportation Inspector General reported in August 2012 that in the past two decades, wildlife strikes have increased from 1,770 reported in 1990 to 9,840 reported in 2011, a greater than five-fold increase. Thirdly, although not at the level of importance as protection of aircraft and deterrence of birds from wind farm turbine rotors, worldwide seafood demand has grown annually by 8.3 percent since 1970. This means that worldwide aquaculture production has rapidly expanded. Of particularly promising potential are solutions to the mussel farming problems of the international aquaculture industry which is well established in many parts of the world. All producing locations in North America and Europe share a common problem of severe predation loss from diving ducks such as the Common Eider that can be devastating to the mussel producer, with the potential to wipe out an entire crop (100%).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bird species are known to have ultraviolet (UV) visual sensitivity. The recent development of high brightness mono-color UV LED technology enabled the development of non-intrusive, non-lethal, deterrence devices. The high brightness light source is capable of inducing increased awareness and momentary overwhelms the optical senses. We believe that the deterrence behavioral response is similar to what humans experience as solar glint or glare.

The use of high brightness mon-colored LEDs has enabled the study of the mechanism involved. The results of a multi-year study was published which  investigated the effectiveness of the non-lethal deterrence technique which involves the neurophysiological response of birds' visual system to high brightness ultraviolet light that closely match the known UV cone spectral sensitivity of birds 4th color cone. The study documented the change in behavioral response of wild birds in their natural environment as they pursued their natural food source.

Multiple prototype UV wildlife deterrence systems designs were developed and tested with power ratings between 100Watts and more than 1000Watts of UV light with narrow band spectrum located between 350-400 nm.  These wavelengths of light are ‘invisible’ to humans. Each of the proof of concept device designs served as product prototypes that were redesigned for reliability and optimum performance.

A spot light with wildlife deterrence was designed, built, and has been sold to assist airports with the management of wildlife on the airport property. The design allows for the mounting onto a pickup and the use of 12/24VDC power from the vehicle.

An aircraft landing light with wildlife deterrence has designed, built, and flown on a UAV in the vicinity of flocks of birds. Investigation of the effectiveness in an aviation environment is continuing post-NSF grant under a FAA research contract. The form factor of the aircraft landing light is plug-in replacement compatible with existing PAR 46 air vehicle equipment. Further development effort is required to commercialize this design. The Aviation Program at the Nashua Community College provided support during the initial design effort.

A beacon-style light with wildlife deterrence was designed and built to assist with the management of wildlife on the airport property, buildings, high value agricultural sites, etc. The focused light beam enables long distance deterrence. The design can be powered with AC or DC and is remotely monitored and controlled through mesh network radio system.

A multi-LED unit was designed and built to assist with the management of wildlife in confined spaces; rafters of hangers, buildings, glass windows, open doorways, etc. The un-focused light beam illuminates a wide area, which provides short distance deterrence. The design can be powered with AC or DC and is remotely monitored and controlled through mesh network radio system.

Numerous materials issues and power supply issues were encountered and overcome. High intensity, high energy UV light was found to degrade 'UV transparent' polycarbonate material during long term reliability tests. A newly introduced silicone material (DOW chemical) was found to overcome the long term degradation problem. The sub-second pulsing of high amperage DC current exceeded the capabilities of many off-the-shelf power supplies. We found DC/DC current demand resulting from the high current in-rush shortened the life of many electrical components and often induced a high frequency AC component to the DC power supply. Custom power circuits were designed and fabricated.

The 3D printing of 'UV transparent' polycarbonate and silicone material adaptation of an extrusion formulations was investigated by Tuskegee University. This resulted in the successful demonstration of material compatible with 3D printing techniques to provide an encapsulating layer to protect wire bonded LEDs and electronic circuits.

The redesign effort resulted in the development of products capable of being deployed at airports, on airplanes, on wind turbines, and at numerous agricultural, aquaculture, and open-air toxic pits (mining, oil, etc.) sites. The design constraints of the system; power, size, performance, and safety requirements, vary from application to application.

A new non-lethal wildlife deterrence technique has been demonstrated that can minimize the negative impact of human-wildlife interactions. The cost of aircraft bird strikes is estimated to exceed $800m/year in the US alone. The cost to agricultural and aquaculture production losses is $billions/year. The intangible cost to safety, nuisance consideration, and value to quality-of-life are difficult to measure.
